#Text=Stephen G. Weber
#Text=Not to be confused with Steven Weber ( professor ) .
#Text=Stephen G. Weber is a professor of chemistry and clinical translational science at the University of Pittsburgh .
#Text=He researches analytical separations theory and its application , and has developed " green " techniques for molecular recognition and microextractions .
#Text=He is particularly interested in the identification of peptides and dipeptides , and their effects on neurochemistry .
#Text=He has received a number of awards , including the 2016 Dal Nogare Award for " contributions to the fundamental understanding of the chromatographic process " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=Education
#Text=Weber attended Case Western Reserve University , receiving his BA in Chemistry and Biology in 1970 . [ 1 ]
#Text=He then worked with Irving Sunshine at the Cuyahoga County Coroner ’s Office , in the Forensic Toxicology group .
#Text=After enlisting in the U.S. Navy , he helped to establish a drug analysis lab in the Great Lakes Naval Hospital at the Great Lakes Naval Station .
#Text=He returned to university in 1974 . [ 2 ]
#Text=For his doctorate , Weber worked with William Purdy , first at the University of Maryland and then at McGill University . [ 2 ]
#Text=He received his Ph.D. from McGill University in 1979 . [ 1 ]
#Text=His research at McGill involved the development of an electrochemical immunoassay using an electrochemical detector . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=In 1979 , Weber joined the Department of Chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh , [ 2 ] where he is currently a Professor of Chemistry and Clinical Translational Science . [ 3 ]
#Text=He has served in a number of capacities at the university , including becoming Director of Graduate Studies for the Chemistry Department in 2001 . [ 4 ]
#Text=He has published over 200 journal articles , and has served on the editorial boards of Analytical Chemistry , Trends in Analytical Chemistry and the Journal of Chromatography . [ 2 ]
#Text=Research
#Text=A major focus of his research is analytical separations theory and its application .

#Text=His research group develops analytical techniques for molecular recognition and molecularly selective microextractions , and utilizes “ green ” separation procedures using aqueous solutions and nonvolatile polymeric systems .
#Text=They have developed thin films for solid-phase micro extraction ( SPME ) . [ 4 ]
#Text=Weber develops electrochemical detectors for use with liquid chromatography techniques . [ 5 ]
#Text=An important area of application is the identification of peptides , which help to control the body .
#Text=Some of the systems which neuropeptides influence include pain , mood , social and emotional behavior , responses to stress , and memory . [ 3 ]
#Text=Understanding how peptides affect neurochemistry and other biological systems has important implications for medicine and pharmaceutical development . [ 1 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=Dipeptides can be present in the brain at sub-picomole levels . [ 6 ]
#Text=To work effectively at this level , techniques must be highly sensitive and selective . [ 4 ]
#Text=Weber and his colleagues work on techniques to sample minute quantities from brain fluid and from single living cells .
#Text=They are developing specialized sampling protocols with the goal of obtaining minute amounts of material from living organisms with minimal damage . [ 3 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Awards and honors
#Text=2016 , Dal Nogare Award , Chromatography Forum of the Delaware Valley [ 1 ]
#Text=2015 , Palmer Award , Minnesota Chromatography Forum [ 8 ]
#Text=2012 , Provost ’s Award for Excellence in Mentoring , University of Pittsburgh [ 9 ]
#Text=2008 , Pittsburgh Award , American Chemical Society [ 4 ]
